questions.question:
Question 1: Antepartum hemorrhage is defined as bleeding from the genital tract after  
.
questions.explanation:
Antepartum haemorrhage (APH) is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract after 28 
weeks of gestation up to the delivery of the baby. The lower limit is the period of viability and the 
upper limit includes the 1st and 2nd stages of labour. Causes of APH: • Placental causes: • Abruptio placenta (most common) • Placenta previa (2nd most common) • Circumvallate placenta • Circummarginate placenta • Fetal causes: • Vasa previa • Extraplacental causes (local cervicovaginal lesions): • Local trauma • Varicose veins • Cervical polyp 379 
Sold by @itachibot • Carcinoma cervix. Note: According to RCOG criteria, the lower limit for APH is 24 weeks. However, in India, the 
period of viability is 28 weeks, so it is taken as the lower limit for APH.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Abruptio placenta is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage (APH). Placental abruption or abruptio placenta is the premature separation of a normally situated 
placenta. The bleeding can be revealed, concealed or mixed type. Causes of APH: • Placental causes: • Abruptio placenta (most common) • Placenta previa (2nd most common) • Circumvallate placenta • Circummarginate placenta • Fetal causes: • Vasa previa • Extraplacental causes (local cervicovaginal lesions): • Local trauma • Varicose veins • Cervical polyp • Carcinoma cervix.

questions.question:
Question 3: Transvaginal ultrasound findings in a multiparous woman revealed a low lying placenta. 
What does this mean?

options.a: Placental edge within 2 cm from the internal os
options.b: Placental edge within 3 cm from the internal os
options.c: Placental edge within 4 cm from the internal os

questions.explanation:
In low lying placenta, the edge of the placenta lies within 2 cm from the internal os but does not 
cover the internal os. Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted over the lower uterine segment 
(partially or completely). ACOG classification of placenta previa: • True placenta previa - placenta covers the internal os partially or completely • Low lying placenta - placenta does not cover the internal os but the edge is within 2 cm of the 
internal os 380 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following types are included in the major degrees of placenta previa?
questions.explanation:
Major degree of placenta previa includes posterior marginal, partial and complete central. Clinical classification of placenta previa: • Mild degree • Type I or lateral or low lying • Type II anterior or anterior marginal • Major degree • Type II posterior or posterior marginal or dangerous placenta previa • Type III or partial central • Type IV or complete Older (Browne's) classification of placenta previa: Type 
Position

questions.question:
Question 5: A 30-year-old multiparous woman presented at 32 weeks of gestation with complaints of 
recurrent painless vaginal bleeding. On examination, fundal height corresponded to 
gestational age and fetal heart rate was 140 bpm. Which of the following is not a risk factor 
for this condition?
questions.explanation:
381 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa. Pre-eclampsia is a risk factor for 
abruptio placenta, not placenta previa. Painless bleeding PV, fundal height proportional to gestational age and presence of FHS are the 
differentiating features of placenta previa from abruptio placenta. Risk factors for placenta previa are: • Demographic factors • Maternal age >35 years • Multiparity • Cigarette smoking • Clinical factors • Prior caesarean section • Past history of placenta previa • Artificial reproductive technology • Multifetal pregnancy • Succenturiate lobe.

questions.question:
Question 6: Per speculum examination findings in a pregnant woman with vaginal bleeding showed 
placenta protruding through the cervical os. What is the type of placenta previa in this case?
questions.explanation:
Placenta protruding through the internal os on per speculum examination indicates complete 
placenta previa or type IV placenta previa. Older (Browne's) classification of placenta previa: Cervical digital examination must only be done in suspected cases of placenta previa in an 
operation theater with provisions for cesarean section kept ready. Type 
Position

Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient at 34 weeks of gestation presented with placenta previa. Which of the following is 
false about this condition?

options.a: Painful recurrent vaginal bleeding is seen
options.b: The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age

questions.explanation:
Painless recurrent vaginal bleeding is seen in placenta previa. Clinical features of placenta previa: • Bleeding per vaginum - sudden onset, painless, recurrent, bright red in colour, sometimes a 
history of warning haemorrhage is present • Uterus - relaxed, soft, no tenderness, size proportional to the period of gestation • Floating head i.e., persistent displacement of fetal head as it cannot be pushed down into the 
pelvis • Fetal heart sound - present • Stallworthy sign - seen in low lying placenta, especially the posterior type. Slowing of fetal heart 
rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly as pressure is 
relieved, is called Stallworthy sign.

questions.question:
Question 8: 373 
Sold by @itachibot Abdominal examination during a routine antenatal checkup gave a positive Stallworthy sign. 
What could be the most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Stallworthy sign is observed in posterior placenta previa. The slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly 
when the pressure is relieved, is called Stallworthy sign. Note: This sign is not always significant as this could also occur in normal pregnancies due to fetal 
head compression. 383 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A G2P1 woman presents to the casualty at 30 weeks with a history of self-limiting painless 
bleeding PV 3 hours ago. On examination, BP - 110/70 mmHg and PR - 80 bpm. What is the 
next best step in management?

options.a: Transvaginal ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis
options.b: Start injection corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of antepartum haemorrhage (APH) due to placenta previa 
(painless bleeding PV). The next step in the management is to confirm the diagnosis with 
transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) as the patient is stable. Transabdominal ultrasound (TAS) is used to detect the cause of APH. If the placenta is in the lower uterine segment on TAS, confirmation of placenta previa is done by 
TVS. TVS provides a clearer image of the relationship between the edge of the placenta and the 
internal cervical os than TAS. Approach to placenta previa after confirmation with TVS: • Minor placenta previa - repeat USG at 36 weeks • Major placenta previa or accreta - USG at 32 weeks followed by elective caesarean delivery • Bleeding present - individual management On TAS, if the placenta is in the upper uterine segment with evidence of retroplacental blood clot, 
abruptio placenta is suspected. Per vaginal examination in placenta previa must not be done as it may further separate the 
placenta and cause excessive bleeding. However, transvaginal ultrasound is safe as long as the 
probe is 2-3 cm away from the cervix.

questions.question:
Question 10: A G2P1L1 woman at 30 weeks of gestation was rushed to the casualty with complaints of 
painless vaginal bleeding. She had woken up to find herself in a pool of blood. On 
examination, her vitals were unstable. Active bleeding per vaginum was present. Which of the 
following complications would not be anticipated in her?
questions.explanation:
Then given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa and precipitate labour is not a 
complication. Precipitate labour is seen in abruptio placenta and uterine tachysystole. Vaginal bleeding in placenta previa is sudden in onset, recurrent, painless, unrelated to activity, 
and often occurs during sleep. Complications of placenta previa: Maternal complications: Fetal complications: • Low birth weight • Asphyxia • Intrauterine death • Birth injuries • Congenital malformations. Period 
Complication Antepart 
um Antepartum haemorrhageMa 
lpresentationPreterm labour 384 
Sold by @itachibot Period 
Complication Early rupture of membranesS 
low dilatation of cervix Intrapart 
um Postpart

um SepsisSubinvolution

questions.question:
Question 11: Transvaginal ultrasound in a multiparous woman at 32 weeks confirmed placenta previa. Her 
vitals are stable and there is no active bleeding PV. What is the next step in management?

options.c: Manage as per McAfee and Johnson method
options.d: Manage as per Sher and Page grading

questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the next best step of management is conservative management till 
37 weeks i.e., McAfee and Johnson's regimen. The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without 
compromising maternal health. Prerequisites: • Blood for transfusion • Facilities for cesarean section Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: • Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) • Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks • No active vaginal bleeding • Fetus reactive on cardiotocography and no congenital anomalies on USG Conduct of expectant treatment: • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity • Bed rest or pelvic rest • Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding PV • Fetal surveillance with USG • Tocolytics if contractions are present • Anti-D to all Rh-negative unsensitized women Option A: Immediate caesarean section after resuscitation is done if the patient is unstable. Option B: Vaginal delivery is considered when the edge of the placenta is >2 cm away from the 
internal os. Option D: Sher and Page grading is for abruptio placenta.

questions.question: Question 12: Suitable cases for expectant management in case of placenta previa include all except:
questions.explanation:
385 
Sold by @itachibot The duration of pregnancy must be less than 37 weeks for expectant management which was 
advocated by McAfee and Johnson. The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without 
compromising maternal health. Prerequisites: • Availability of blood for transfusion • Facilities for cesarean section available Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: • Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) • Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks • No active vaginal bleeding • Fetus normal on USG and reactive on CTG Conduct of expectant treatment: • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity • Bed rest or pelvic rest • Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding pv • Fetal surveillance with USG • Tocolytics if contractions are present • Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.question: Question 13: What is the most common cause of consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics?
questions.explanation:
Placental abruption is the most common cause of severe consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics. Consumptive coagulopathy, also known as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), is a 
pathologic disruption of hemostasis. It is characterized by systemic activation of blood 
coagulation, which results in thrombosis and fibrin deposition in the small blood vessels 
throughout the body. Other causes of DIC in pregnancy: • Amniotic fluid embolism • Sepsis • Preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy • Postpartum haemorrhage. 386 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following does not increase the risk of placental abruption?
questions.explanation: Post term pregnancy does not increase the risk of abruptio placenta. Risk factors for placental abruption: • Prior abruption • Increased age and parity • Pre-eclampsia and chronic hypertension • Chorioamnionitis • Preterm ruptured membranes • Multifetal gestation • Cocaine use • Cigarette smoking • Uterine leiomyomas • Single umbilical artery.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following clinical features can be seen in a patient presenting with accidental 
haemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Abruptio placenta is also known as accidental haemorrhage or premature separation of placenta. 
Tender uterus is seen in abruptio placenta. Abruptio placenta is defined as premature separation of a normally situated placenta. It is of the 
following types: • Concealed • Revealed • Mixed Clinical features of abruptio placenta: In mixed type, features of concealed variety will be predominant. Features

questions.question:
Question 16: A multiparous woman at 34 weeks of gestation presented with bleeding per vaginum and was 
diagnosed to have grade 2 abruptio placenta. Which of the following features may be seen in 
her?
questions.explanation:
Grade 2 abruptio placenta is characterized by fetal distress. Sher and Page clinical classification of placental abruption: Grade 0 of abruptio placenta is seen in an asymptomatic patient, where a retroplacental clot is 
observed only after delivery of placenta. Feature

questions.question:
Question 17: A 23-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the labour room with lower 
abdominal pain. Her vitals are BP - 90/60 mmHg and PR - 120 bpm. Fetal distress was noted 
and she was taken up for a caesarean section. The uterus appears as shown below. Which of 
the following is true regarding this condition?

options.a: It is seen in revealed abruptio placenta
options.b: It is an indication for hysterectomy
options.c: It is a case of uteroplacental apoplexy

questions.explanation:
The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severe 
forms of concealed abruptio placenta. There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, the 
uterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broad 
ligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity. It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.

questions.question:
Question 18: Colour doppler studies in a patient with velamentous cord insertion revealed fetal vessels 
which were overlying the cervical os. Which of the following is false regarding her condition?

options.b: Bleeding is triggered by membrane rupture
options.c: Bleeding is managed by category I caesarian section

questions.explanation:
The doppler findings are suggestive of vasa previa. Maternal mortality is not seen in vasa previa, 
but fetal mortality is seen. Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical 
os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture. Fetal mortality is high and is due to fetal exsanguination. 388 
Sold by @itachibot Investigations of vasa previa: • Colour flow Doppler (TVS) • Singer's alkali denaturation test - to detect nucleated red blood cells • Apt test (alkali denaturation test) - to detect fetal haemoglobin Management of vasa previa: • No bleeding • 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids • 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance • 37 weeks - elective caesarean section • Bleeding present • Category I emergency caesarean section is done (immediate threat to the life of mother or fetus 
and decision delivery interval <30 mins)

questions.question:
Question 19: Sample from a patient with bleeding PV at 30 weeks showed a positive Apt test. What is the 
most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal haemoglobin (HbF). It is positive in vasa 
previa and Rh incompatibility. Apt test is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. It 
is done by taking the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding 10% NaOH. 
Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube. Bleeding due to vasa previa must be managed immediately with an emergency caesarean section. 
Hence, Apt test is not practically done in all cases. Other options: Bleeding due to cervical polyp, placenta previa, and abruptio placenta is of 
maternal origin. So, Apt test will be negative in these cases. 389 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following investigations can be used in the antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa in 
a patient with no history of bleeding PV?
questions.explanation:
The antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa can be done by colour doppler. Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical 
os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture. Fetal mortality is high due to fetal exsanguination. Investigations of vasa previa: • Colour flow Doppler (TVS) • Singer's alkali denaturation test - to detect nucleated red blood cells • Apt test - to detect fetal haemoglobin Management of vasa previa: • No bleeding • 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids • 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance • 37 weeks - elective caesarean section • Bleeding present • Emergency caesarean section done by category I Options A and B: Colour Doppler is superior to MRI and TAS in the antenatal diagnosis of vasa 
previa. Option D: Singer's alkali denaturation test to detect fetal RBCs can be used in intrapartum 
diagnosis of vasa previa (as there might be bleeding).

questions.question:
Question 21: A multiparous woman at term presents to the labour room with bleeding per vaginum and 
ruptured membranes. NST shows fetal distress and sinusoidal heart rate pattern. How will 
you manage this patient?

options.a: Rapid induction and delivery by vacuum
options.b: Rapid induction and delivery by forceps
options.d: Adopt Vagos method and rapid vaginal delivery

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of vasa previa since bleeding is associated with fetal 
distress and sinusoidal pattern in NST. Actively bleeding vasa previa in a term gestation is 
managed by immediate LSCS. Sinusoidal pattern in CTG is a regular, smooth, undulating signal resembling a sine wave. It can 
be seen in conditions associated with severe fetal anemia like: • Anti-D allo-immunisation • Fetal-maternal haemorrhage • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome • Ruptured vasa previa • Acute fetal hypoxia • Infection 390 
Sold by @itachibot • Cardiac malformations • Hydrocephalus • Gastroschisis Sinusoidal pattern on CTG: Management of vasa previa: • No bleeding • 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids • 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance • 37 weeks - elective caesarean section • Bleeding present • Emergency caesarean section Note: Vagos method is used in the management of umbilical cord prolapse.

questions.question:
Question 22: The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism includes all except  
.
questions.explanation:
The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism does not include metabolic acidosis. Classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism: • Hypotension • Hypoxia • DIC Conditions predisposing to the development of amniotic fluid embolism: • Rapid labour 391 
Sold by @itachibot • Meconium-stained amniotic fluid • Tears in uterine and other large pelvic veins • Older maternal age • Post-term pregnancy • Labour induction or augmentation • Eclampsia • Cesarean/forceps/vacuum delivery • Placental abruption/placenta previa • Polyhydramnios.

questions.question:
Question 23: A G2P1L1 woman presented with placental abruption and was delivered by normal vaginal 
delivery. The next day, she develops petechiae, cold extremities, and her BP drops to 90/60 
mmHg. Her blood reports show increased FDP, D-dimer, and decreased platelets. Which of 
the following is not used in the management of her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). 
Epsilon-aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid are not used in the treatment of DIC. Evaluation and management of DIC: • Vigorous restoration and maintenance of circulation to treat hypotension • Crystalloids and colloids to treat hypotension • Whole blood and packed cells • Fresh frozen plasma - contains fibrinogen, antithrombin III, factors V, XI, XII • Cryoprecipitate - contains fibrinogen, factor VIII, von Willebrand’s factor, factor XIII • Platelet replacement if low • Identification of the cause: • Abruptio placenta • PPH • HELLP syndrome • Amniotic fluid embolism • Sepsis • Acute fatty liver • Assess the fetal condition and plan for termination of pregnancy. 392 
Sold by @itachibot Postpartum Haemorrhage
